required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on April 10, 2017
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: ED Lung Protective Ventilation to Reduce Complications
clinical_study.official_title: The Effect of Lung Protective Ventilation Initiated in the Emergency Department on the Incidence of Pulmonary Complications and Clinical Outcomes

brief_summary.textblock: Early mechanical ventilation, if delivered with injurious settings, can lead to pulmonary complications, such as acute respiratory distress syndrome (ARDS). Mechanical ventilation in the emergency department (ED) has been studied infrequently when compared to the intensive care unit; however, data suggests that ED-based mechanical ventilation has significant room for improvement and may also be a causative factor in ARDS incidence.

primary_outcome.measure: Number of patients progressing to ARDS after admission from the emergency department
Number of patients that experience ventilator-associated conditions after admission from the emergency department

secondary_outcome.measure: Number of patients that die during the hospitalization
secondary_outcome.time_frame: Patients will be followed for the duration of hospital stay, up to 52 weeks

intervention.description: Lung protective ventilation strategy, which aims to deliver safe tidal volumes, appropriate PEEP, limit plateau pressure, and limit hyperoxia.

study_pop.textblock: mechanically ventilated patients in the emergency department

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:
- mechanically ventilated via an endotracheal tube in the ED
Exclusion Criteria:
- death in the ED,
- death or discontinuation of ventilation within 24 hours,
- chronic mechanical ventilation,
- transfer to another hospital.

facility.name: Washinton University School of Medicine in St. Louis

responsible_party.investigator_title: Assistant Professor of Anesthesiology and Emergency Medicine
